subject: thoughts to live by
verse: I have loved you with an everlasting love. With unfailing love I have drawn you to Myself. (Jeremiah 31:3)
reflection: I remember one time [many years ago] in which I received a picture of a friend, on the back she had written, "I love you with all my heart. I will love you forever." But under her signature was this PS: "If we ever break up, I want this picture back." God's love doesn't change with the wind or passing emotions. God's love is permanent and so is what He in His love has done for us. When He says, "[I] so loved the world that [I] gave [My] one and only Son, that whoever believes in Him shall not perish but have eternal life" (John 3:16), that's as true today as it was when His words were recorded more than 2, 000 years ago. When the apostle wrote, "He [God] loved us and sent His Son as an atoning sacrifice for our sins" (I John 4:10), that stands for us just as for those who first read John's words.
prayer: Dear Lord I thank You for the assurance of Your unchanging love. Amen.

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: God said to him, "You fool! this very night your life will be demanded of you." (Luke 12:20)
reflection: As you know this is the month we observe Labor Day, have you asked yourself the question "What am I laboring for? Is it for how much I can get or how much I can keep??? Jesus calls the man in the parable a "fool" not because of his laboring but because all he could talk about was "I" and "Mine". All that man could think about was how much he could get. The same temptation is there for us. We eat vitamin-enriched foods, ride in air-conditioned cars, whatch TV programs beamed across the miles, lose our anxieties by taking pills, die without pain because of modern drugs, and are laid to rest in park-like cemeteries. All this we have and most of it is good. But what good is my life if it revolves only around these things. As the man in the parable ~ we cannot prolong our life a single second, pay God for a single sin, or buy one square inch of heaven. Are you too asking the wrong question, one about getting instead of giving??? To be rich toward God means to treasure the pardon He has prepared for us in Christ, to use our earthly treasures for the spreading of His Word, to look forward to our rich inheritance with Him in heaven. Labor? For what? The question is simple, deceptively so. The answer is serious, eternally so.
prayer: Dear Lord, give me the right answer in the Savior Jesus Christ. Amen.

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: "Blessed are the poor in spirit, for theirs is the kingdom of heaven." (Matthew 5:3)
reflection: Happiness is. How would you finish that sentence? Happiness is having a million dollars? being successful? being able to do what you want? In His Sermon on the Mount, Jesus gives some unexpected answers. Reading them, we must remember that He's speaking to believers. Also He's reminding them not how to be saved but how the saved are to live."Blessed are the poor, " Jesus says, using a word that describes the down-and-out, the penniless, helpless, hopeless beggar. No He's not urging me or you to get rid of all we have if we want His blessing. He says, "The poor in spirit." He's speaking of people like the tax-collector in the temple who had nothing to point to but his sins. Standing as a spiritual pauper before God, he begged, "God, have mercy on me, a sinner." Poor-in-spirit, believers confess their utter sinfulness, count all their efforts as worthless ashes, and commit themselves completely to the Savior's love. Jesus reminds us, "Theirs is the kingdom of heaven." They hold in faith's hand citizenship papers for heaven. They enjoy all the riches of God's kingdom ~ pardon for sins, peace with God, promise of eternal life. In the world's eyes they are poor, but in God's kingdom they are rich.
prayer: Dear Lord, grant me the happiness that only believers in Jesus can have. Amen.

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: "Blessed are those who mourn, for they will be comforted." (Matthew 5:4)
reflection: "Blessed are those who mourn, " Jesus continues in His Sermon on the Mount. With 'mourn' He refers to a grief that grips the heart. What is it that grips my heart the hardest as a believer and makes it grieve the most? If I am to be truthful at all times, I have to say my sin. Christians who are truly Christian mourn deeply over their sins. They do not just go through the motions of confessing them but pour out their hearts to God. When I truly see the nature of my sin, the guilt it lays on me, the damnation it earns me, I mourn in genuine sorrow. But the Savior has what it takes to dry our tears ~ He says that I should be of good cheer, because my sins are forgiven. Do I mourn because life is squeezing me with all its problems? He says, "In all things God works for the good of those who love Him" (Romans 8:28). Does death put its scare into me? He says, "Whoever lives and believes in me will never die" (John 11:26). From Jesus comes comfort here on earth and perfection in heaven at His side. That's why I have happiness.
prayer: Dear Lord, I thank You that Your assurance provides all I need for body and soul. Amen.

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: "Blessed are the meek, for they will inherit the earth." Matthew 5:5)
reflection: Jesus says: "Blessed are the meek." People would rather say, "Blessed are the strong." "Blessed are those who go after what they want." "Blessed are the ones who stick up for their rights." Meek Christians live humbly before their God. They submit their lives to God's will and humbly follow God's Word. For them the question "What does God want?" comes before what would I like?" Toward their neighbors too they exhibit a meek spirit. When hurt, the meek don't hit back. When taken advantage of, they don't scheme how to get even. When disagreements arise, they don't insist on their rights. They leave such injustices to the hand of a just God. How can I do otherwise as a believer??? When I truly realize how poor I am in God's eyes and How much I sin I have to mourn, how can I puff up my chest before God [or] lord over my neighbor who's in the same fix as I am???
prayer: Dear Lord, keep my eyes fixed on heaven's riches so that I live in true meekness. Amen.

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: "Blessed are those who hunger and thirst for righteousness, for they will be filled. (Matthew 5:6)
reflection: When was the last time any of us felt true hunger pangs or thirst's burning sensation??? Patients fresh from surgery or people who have been marooned for days in a snow storm can describe real hunger and thirst. But so can the believer ~ Jesus says "Blessed are those who hunger and thirst for righteousness." If we are truly God's child, we should be constantly hungry and thirsting for the holiness God has prepared for sinners in the Savior. Our eyes of faith can never look enough on the Lamb of God who takes away the sins of the world ~ Our ears can never hear too often of how in Jesus, though our sins be as scarlet, they shall be as white as snow ~ Our lips can never sing too frequently " Plenteous grace with You is found, grace to cover all my sins." As God's child, filled with His forgiveness, I hunger also for a life of righteousness ~ God has made me His child ~ Now He asks me to live as His child. With Christ's strength, I'm to walk in the newness of life reflecting a Christ-likeness. When the world views me they should see one who has true happiness because of God's grace.
prayer: Dear Lord, make me always hungry and thirsty for Your Word with its message of salvation. Amen.

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: "Blessed are the merciful, for they will be shown mercy." (Matthew 5:7)
reflection: True mercy begins in the heart and leads to action. It involves both heart and hand. Want an example??? How about our Lord? He didn't just say of the world which was speeding to Hell: "That's to bad ~ I cry for you." NO! His mercy kicked into high gear. He sent His Son to rescue sinners from hell. In daily life He also shows abundant mercy. He doesn't just say "I feel sorry for those foolish people, " and then let us blow our world to ribbons, or let our worries drive us out of our minds, or our illnesses run unchecked. His mercy acts ~ Every day in every phase of life His mercy takes care of us."Blessed are the merciful, for they will be shown mercy, " Jesus says. He knew how difficult showing mercy could be in this world. So He encourages me with His promise to show me mercy in every need. What a Lord I have ~ First He makes me merciful by bringing me faith, then He promises me more mercy when I try to be like Him toward those in need. In His promise we can all have happiness.
prayer: Dear Lord, scrub the selfishness out of my heart by showering Your mercy upon me. Amen.

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: "Blessed are the pure in heart, for they will see God." (Matthew 5:8)
reflection: During Jesus' days on earth, people thought the heart was the seat of life. And we still talk that way today. So we should understand that Jesus is referring to every part of us ~ to our thoughts, words, and deeds."Pure" leaves no doubt as to how Jesus wants us to be. He, the holy Lord, demands holiness from us. as the old saying goes, He wants a life that has no bugs on the windshield, no dirt on the wheels, just total sinlessness. Isn't He asking for the impossible? Yes by ourselves we can't clean a single sin from life's windshield or stop even one sin from smearing it more. But what we can't do, Jesus came to do. He died on the cross to cleanse our heart from sin and present it spotless before our Heavenly Father. Now He wants our pure heart to show in our life."Be pure, " He says referring to all our thoughts, words, and deeds. Here on earth we will never reach that ideal. Our life will still be tainted by daily sin. Because life is like riding a bicycle up hill if we stop pedaling we will roll backward. We need the strength to continue a forward motion which comes only from Jesus through His Word. The more we see His loving face in His Word, the more power we'll have to keep pumping the bicycle of holiness up the hill of life. And we will even find happiness in doing so.
prayer: Dear Lord, create a new heart within me that knows the Savior and loves to follow His ways. Amen.

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: Blessed are those who are persecuted because of righteousness, for theirs is the kingdom of heaven. (Matthew 5:10)
reflection: As I read this verse I became aware of how far removed I can be at times from this beatitude! I was reminded of how much I will do to avoid being persecuted for following Jesus. Its true I go places, laugh at jokes, do things I shouldn't so that the world around me won't pick on me. How often I'm hesitant to stand up for Jesus, much less suffer for Him. I'll slip into the shadows of silence instead of speaking up for what His Word says. I'll even pull back when He asks some service or offering from me, so I won't be inconvenienced. We need to remember, Jesus doesn't talk about taking up a pillow and following Him ~ He mentions a cross. Jesus doesn't promise that the road of discipleship will be without a bump or danger from competing traffic. He describes our life as a race that requires every ounce of our endurance and every minute of faith's concentration. I hate to ask the question, but could it be that we haven't found the world to be such a severe enemy because we've been too much of a friend with the world? Let's all take a moment to take stock of the road we have been traveling?
prayer: Lord Help me find happiness in standing up for Jesus and His Word in this hostile world. Amen.

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: God presented Him [Jesus] as a sacrifice of atonement, through faith in His blood. (Romans 3:25)
reflection: Heading back to our room while in Hawaii some years ago we boarded a bus and went directly to our seats, the bus driver said "Hey you have to pay the fare, " so I showed him my pass for the day. The bus driver was right you have to pay to ride. It is somewhat the same principle with the road to heaven. Someone has to pay for the ticket. Only this time it was the eternal Son of God. God is a holy God who can't just wink at sin as if it were of no account. He can't just sweep my many transgressions under the rug as if they didn't matter. Scriptures say very clearly, "The wages of sin is death" (Romans 6:23). The price required was extremely high. Again the Bible says emphatically, "Without the shedding of blood there is no forgiveness" (Hebrews 9:22), the fare for heavens bus was not cheap. It cost God the best He had - His own Son. Jesus paid my fare to heaven with His holy, precious blood. How do we get a ticket on that wonderful bus? Through faith in His blood ~ and the finished work of the cross.
prayer: Dear Lord, thank you for sin's payment. Help me hold on to the free ticket to heaven you gave me. Amen.

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: "Whoever comes to Me I will never drive away." (John 6:37)
reflection: "What's she doing here?" whispered a member to her neighbor in the church pew. Across the aisle a lady, who everyone knew had a shady reputation, had just sat down. Was that member correct? Little did the critic know that the pastor had encouraged the sinner to come. Earlier in the week she had sat in the pastor's office, sobbing out her repentance, seeking forgiveness for what she knew was wrong."Your sins are forgiven, " the pastor had assured her."Come to worship next Sunday, " he encouraged her, "and hear even more of that forgiveness." In this world, though we claim not to, we set up pecking orders. Somewhat a sinner, more so a sinner, and very much a sinner are the categories into which we sort people. And unfortunately we do the same when Christ welcomes a sinner. Have we forgotten what the Savior Himself said? He won't drive away any sinner who comes to Him in repentance. He has no sin-o-meter that weighs one sin more heavily than anther, no list of the 10 or 20 worst sinners. Just full forgiveness to everyone.
prayer: Dear Lord, remind me that the chief of sinners though I be, you shed your blood for me. Amen.

reflection: When my mom gets a certain look on her face, we know her mind is made up. nothing we can say or do or ask will change it."Jesus resolutely set out for Jerusalem, " our verse says. Nothing could stop Him from what lay ahead, He knew what awaited Him in Jerusalem and out on Calvary. He even told His disciples several times in advance. The rejection by His countrymen and the betrayal by His friend, hurry-up trials before the Jewish court and the Roman judge, the crown of thorns and the awful whip, the crude cross and the fleshsplitting nails, the sun-drained darkness of Calvary and the souldraining depths of hell's punishment ~ all this Jesus knew about. Yet He resolutely set out for Jerusalem."Why did Jesus die on the cross?" a five-year-old boy's mom asked as they talked about his Sunday school lesson. After a moment of silence, the boy answered, "Because He couldn't get off." In a sense the little boy was right. Jesus had more than enough power to turn His journey to Jerusalem into something far different than an ending on the cross. BUT HIS LOVE WOULDN'T LET HIM. His love for sinners brought Him to that cross and kept Him on it. There His love poured the lifeblood from His sacred veins for sinners like me. His heart was made up. And that is why He went to Jerusalem.
prayer: Dear Lord, fix my eyes of faith resolutely on Jesus' cross as the only salvation for Sinners. Amen.

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: The people were amazed at His teaching, because He taught them as one who had authority. (Mark 1:22)
reflection: "Congratulations, Mrs. so-and-so, teacher of the year, " said the sign on the brick wall of the middle school. Students had nominated her, the panel had selected her, and she received recognition. They weren't handing out awards that day in the synagogue at Capernaum, but they did recognize Jesus as a good teacher. They sat there amazed, with mouths wide open. It makes one wish that Mark would have recorded Jesus' sermon. But he didn't. He does, however, tell us why the people were so awestruck by Jesus' teaching. It was because "He taught them as one who had authority." It makes me wish I was there. But in His Word, Jesus speaks to us. The Bible is Jesus' voice. In it He teaches us the same beautiful truth ~ that because of His redemption, we have eternal life in heaven, (We who have him in our hearts). That message of divine love still brings astonishment to the ears of the sinner. What a teacher of the world Jesus is!!!
prayer: Dear Lord, open my ears to hear the news of salvation and my heart to rejoice because of it. Amen.

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: For there is one God and one mediator between God and man, the man Christ Jesus, who gave Himself a ransom for all men. (I Tim. 2:5)
reflection: I think this story is so fitting for this text: One day a young boy accidentally broke a neighbor's window with an ice covered snow ball, of course the neighbor went and told his mother. When the young lad finally showed his face, his mom scolded him and said, "Dad will deal with you when he comes home." Anxiously, the boy asked his mom, "You have such a caring heart will you help me deal with dad?" Not some snowball, but our sins have shattered our relationship with God. Even just one sin is enough to put us on the punishment list. WHY? Because a holy God has to demand payment for every sin. How can we stand before Him when it is time to come home??? I don't know about you but I'm not just anxious but terrified. I dread that day coming. I need a mediator with a caring heart to speak to the Father for me. Jesus is my GO-BETWEEN. He not only speaks for me before the Father but does so effectively. The Father listens to Him because Jesus has already paid for the gigantic snowball of sin I roll in life. When the Redeemer mediates between the holy Father and me, the sinner, I'm safe."Forgiven, " With Jesus as my go-between, I can approach the holy God confidently and call Him Father.
prayer: Dear Jesus, when I sin, remind me of Your forgiveness and plead for me before my Father. Amen.

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: We have this hope (Jesus) as an anchor for the soul, firm and secure. (Hebrews 6:19)
reflection: Have you ever flown a kite and all of a sudden the string broke and the kite just sailed off and crashed??? Like that kite our salvation needs a string or as our verse pictures it, an anchor. But, an anchor is only as good as the ground into which it sinks its flukes. Water surely won't work, neither will sand for very long. To hold the boat securely, the anchor needs to be embedded in the right ground. The only anchor in which there is hope of salvation is Jesus Christ. Salvation is found in no one else, for there is no other name under heaven given to men by which we must be saved. (Acts 4:12) This is also made very clear in (John 14:6) "I am the way and the truth and the life. No one comes to the Father except through Me." The Savior Himself says. Yes when we have a personal relationship with Christ, we have our anchor in the right spot.
prayer: Dear Lord, help me continue to realize that my hope of salvation can be built on nothing less than Jesus' blood and righteousness. Amen.

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: "Bit I. when I am lifted up from the earth, will draw all men to Myself." (John 12:32)
reflection: Just as the Savior said, All people would be affected by His being "lifted up from the earth." With this expression Jesus was referring to His crucifixion when He would hang above Calvary's ground. His cross would be a magnet having an effect on all people. Either they will kneel beneath it in faith in the Savior or turn from it in damning unbelief. Salvation through Jesus' death and resurrection either attracts or repels sinners. The woman at the well in Samara, the Roman centurion whose servant was sick, the Greek who came looking for Jesus, are examples of those whom Jesus' love drew to His cross. With His blood shed on the cross, Jesus has, "purchased men ~ from every tribe and language and people and nation" (Revelation 5:9). He has also paid for me and wants His cross to draw me to Him as my only Savior.
prayer: Dear Lord, may the gospel message of salvation draw and keep me always close to the Savior. Amen.

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: God is our refuge. (Psalm 46:1)
reflection: How unprotected people must feel who don't know about God's mighty arms! How afraid are those who don't trust His arms to hold them safely! When their sins crash into them like a speeding car, where do they turn? When life's uncertainties spook them, what's their refuge? When their last day draws near, and they stand before the judge, what's their hiding place? Thank God for my Father's arms. Because of Jesus' payment for sins, those arms are there for me. Because of the Spirit's gift of faith, I trust those arms. When Satan comes stalking me like some roaring lion seeking to sink his teeth into my soul, I find strength in God's protecting arms. When sin has done its daily damage to my soul, I find forgiveness each night in God's loving arms. When life's storm clouds gather over me, I find shelter in God's almighty arms.
prayer: Dear Heavenly Father, cover my defenseless head with the shadow of Thy wing. Amen.

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: God is our ~~~ strength. (Psalm 46:1)
reflection: Sometimes I don't feel weak. I flex my physical and my spiritual muscles like some beefed-up weight lifter and think that I can heft any amount. That's how the world entices us to feel. But how soon my muscles turn to flab. It may be an illness that pushes me on the ropes, and I throw in the towel. A loved one has a problem my muscles can't lift, and I turn away in frustration. The years speed by, and my strength degenerates into debilitating weakness. Worst of all, if I am a thinking person, I worry about sin, that little word with big consequences. Deep down because of it I know that all is not well between God and me. Deep down I realize when my end comes, I must give an accounting to Him. Speak about weakness ~ here's an area where I have no strength or muscles at all."I am weak but He is strong, " an old spiritual says. Yes God is the strength of my life ~ He helps me climb the steepest mountain, cross the deepest river, cross the widest desert of life. God is the rock of my salvation. He has canceled sin's curse, closed hell's door, cracked open forever heaven's door through His Son's payment on Calvary's cross. In Him I find the strength I need.
prayer: Dear Lord, fill me with Your strength. continually lead me to trust Your Son for my salvation. Amen

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: God is. an ever-present help in trouble. (Psalm 46:1)
reflection: A great number of us carry cell phones while traveling today so in case of trouble we can call 911 and help will soon be on the way. As a believer I don't need a cell phone to call God to my side. He is there all the time."An ever-present help in trouble" is how the Psalmist describes Him. My greatest trouble is sin. It's at the root of all the worlds problems. Sin is the soil in which the troubles of man grow ~ all his pains, temptations, even death. Every day the dandelions of sin shoot up in my heart, threatening to choke out all else. Daily I must confess that I sin much and deserve nothing but punishment. So what do I do? ~ Pick up the cell phone and call 911? Man can't help me, but God did. He sent His Son to pay sin's penalty and destroy sin's curse. On the cross he provided the only help that works, His Son's blood in payment for all my sins and as power against sin's temptations. Through His Word He stands at my (our) side with that forgiveness. His Word is our "cell phone."
prayer: Be near me Lord Jesus, to help me with my sins and bless me with Your forgiveness. Amen.

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: No man can redeem the life of another or give to God a ransom for him ~ the ransom for a life is costly. (Psalm 49:7, 8)
reflection: What's a life worth? "Nothing, " some say as they snuff it out inside the womb or outside in the world."About ten dollars, " the scientist calculates as he analyzes the chemicals in the human body."Precious, " God answers as He looks at what He has given ~ And His answer is the one that counts. Life is a gift that only God can give ~ Every moment of our life is His gift to us. Just as with other gifts from God, life has a purpose, In fact, it purpose makes life a most precious gift. It's the time a loving God grants each individual to learn of the Savior Jesus and be readied for heaven through Him. Because of this purpose, God carefully protects life, commanding others to keep their sinful hands off the time of grace He gives each person. Only the blood of God's own Son could pay the ransom required to restore sinful man to his Creator. That God should send His Son to pay the ultimate price of His atoning death plainly indicates what value God has attached to people. What are we worth? ~ Nothing as a sinner, but we are precious in God's sight because of His love and Jesus blood.
prayer: Dear Heavenly Father, thank You for life. Even more thank You for Jesus through whom I have eternal life. Amen.

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: "Come, you who are blest by My Father; take your inheritance, the Kingdom prepared for you since the creation of the world. (Matthew 25:34)
reflection: Faith is invisible. No one can look into another's heart to see whether faith is there. And yet faith is very visible. On the last day, Jesus will point to faith visible in the lives of believers. He will reference the works they have done as outward indication of the invisible faith in their hearts. Unfortunately, some still misunderstand that salvation is something done for us not by us. We need to note that Jesus uses the word inheritance. An inheritance is a gift from the donor not some wage earned by my efforts. So the kingdom of heaven is God's free gift, graciously willed to me because of what His Son has done. To make it even clearer, Jesus calls it the kingdom prepared "for you" not "by you." God has done all the work.
prayer: Dear Lord, When I stand in glory at Your side, all my praise shall be that You did it all for me. Amen.
